Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines three properties of underground cybercrime communities: 1) profitability, 2) connectivity, 3) and sustainability. It identifies qualitative and quantitative metrics for these properties as well as discusses the relative effectiveness of distinct operationalization of these metrics under different levels of data granularity. The goal is to develop metrics that provide meaning indicators even when data is limited. for example, if public posts are available but not private messages between individual cybercriminals. The analysis targets five underground forums: AntiChat, BadHacke, BlackhatWorld, Carders, and L33tCrew. Finally, the project combines linguistic techniques, e.g. topic modeling, social network analysis, and analysis to provide a repeatable, verifiable, and systematic framework that enables a scientific exploration of these forums and the impact of distinct interventions at mitigating underground forums.

This project assumes that cybercrime is made economically feasible by collaboration between criminals with specialized skills, as facilitated by underground forums. Thus, it argues to change the fundamental focus of anti-cybercrime efforts from making individual incidence of cybercrime unprofitable to making cybercrime communities unsustainable. The findings inform defender efforts, both for academic researchers as well as practitioners. The project builds a scientific framework to evaluate the effectiveness of such interventions. This framework is being used to develop tools for law enforcement as well as pedagogical material to educate students in cyber-security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a scientific approach to cybercrime research, specifically to understand the economics of unground forums and determine appropriately efficient deterrence strategies.
1. How is trust managed in underground cybercriminal forums?
2. What is the effectiveness of trust management strategies on these forums?
3. When can these management tools leveraged for anti­-cybercrime enforcement efforts?

The project resulted in several academic publications studying how cybercriminals manage trust in underground forums and how such forums are organized—with comparisons to other forms of organized crime. This analysis was performed with a combination of coding manually read messages, social network analysis, and natural language processing techniques. The project also developed methods for detecting users of multiple identities/accounts and studied how these identities are used in underground forums. The methods for detecting multiple accounts were shared with FBI computer scientists. The project also compared the public messages on cybercriminal forums with private messages. The project also produced a qualitative study of the value of online anonymity and how it is used by non-criminals to address privacy concerns.
The project contributed to the education of three female Ph.D. students and the mentorship of one postdoctoral scholar. Elements of the research were integrated into security courses developed and taught by the PIs and other faculty.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2016
Modified by: Rachel Greenstadt
